ChatGPT said:

Here’s a structured 3-week learning plan to master Make.com — designed for beginners to intermediate users. You can follow it part-time (~1–2 hours per day).

✅ 3-Week Learning Plan for Make.com

🔹 Week 1 – Foundation & Basics

DayTopicsActivities
Day 1Introduction to Make.comRead what Make.com is, use cases, and benefits. Sign up and explore the dashboard.
Day 2Terminology & ConceptsLearn: Scenarios, Modules, Operations, Connections, Iterators, Aggregators.
Day 3UI TourUnderstand scenario editor, toolbar, module configuration, history & logs.
Day 4Build First ScenarioTry: Gmail (Watch Email) → Google Sheets (Create Row).
Day 5Explore TemplatesBrowse Make Templates, try 2–3 simple ones.
Day 6Filters & RoutersAdd logic: filters (if/else), routers (branches).
Day 7Review + PracticeRebuild any 2 workflows without templates. Reflect on learnings.

🔹 Week 2 – Intermediate Skills

DayTopicsActivities
Day 8Iterators & AggregatorsLearn to loop through arrays and group items. Use sample JSON.
Day 9Working with VariablesUse Set Variable and map values across steps.
Day 10Scheduling & TriggersLearn time-based triggers, event triggers, and Run once.
Day 11Error HandlingAdd Break, Continue, or Ignore for module errors.
Day 12Webhooks (Intro)Create custom webhooks. Test with form submissions or Postman.
Day 13Advanced FiltersCombine conditions, logical operators (AND, OR, NOT).
Day 14Midpoint ProjectBuild a real-world workflow: Example – Twitter post to Google Sheets log.

🔹 Week 3 – Advanced Automation & API Integration

DayTopicsActivities
Day 15HTTP Module BasicsUse Make a request to call a public API (e.g., JSONPlaceholder).
Day 16Authentication in APIsUse headers, tokens, query params. Try a GET and POST API call.
Day 17Parse & Map JSONUse “Parse JSON” or built-in mapping to access values.
Day 18Build Complex ScenarioMix webhook, iterator, API call, and filter.
Day 19Real-World Use CaseAutomate a workflow from your team (e.g., form → Slack → DB).
Day 20Optimize ScenariosCheck history, reduce operations, reuse modules.
Day 21Wrap-Up & Next StepsReview all concepts, explore Make Academy certifications.

🧠 Optional Resources:

  • Make Academy – Free learning platform

  • YouTube Playlist (Official)

  • Community Forum

You said:
Intro to Make.com What it is, use cases, key benefits give me explanation , how to learn
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! Let’s break down “Intro to Make.com” step-by-step — tailored for you as a tester and non-developer.

✅ 1. What is Make.com?

Make.com is a no-code automation platform that lets you connect different apps and services (like Gmail, Google Sheets, Slack, JIRA, etc.) to automate repetitive tasks — without writing any code.

Think of it like:

📦 "If X happens, then automatically do Y, Z, and send a report."

It uses a visual interface (drag-and-drop), so even if you don’t code, you can design smart workflows using logic.

✅ 2. Key Terms (Simple Explanation)

TermWhat It Means
ScenarioA complete automation workflow
ModuleA single action (like “Send Email” or “Add Row to Sheet”)
ConnectionThe login/access to an external app (like Gmail or Slack)
TriggerThe event that starts the automation (e.g. “New Email”)
ActionThe steps that follow the trigger
FilterA condition (e.g. “only if email is from John”)
IteratorLoops through a list or array (e.g. each row in a sheet)

✅ 3. What Can You Automate? (Use Cases for Testers)

Use CaseExample
Test Logs CollectionEvery new bug in Jira → Log in Google Sheets
Notification AlertsNew test failure in TestRail → Slack alert
ReportingScheduled test report → Send to team every morning
Form SubmissionsForm → Send data to email + save to database
Test CoverageAutomatically update a dashboard when new test cases are added

✅ 4. Why It’s Useful for Testers

  • 🧠 You can automate repetitive QA tasks

  • 📥 Save time from manual logging, tracking, and notifications

  • 🔄 Integrate tools you already use (Jira, Slack, Excel, TestRail, Postman)

  • ✅ Better visibility into QA processes, bugs, or test status

✅ 5. How to Learn This Step (Time: ~30 mins to 1 hour)

Here’s a step-by-step guide to complete this topic.

🔹 A. Watch 1 Short Intro Video (~10 mins)

📺 YouTube (Official):
Video: What is Make.com? - Overview

🔹 B. Read the Official Beginner Guide (~15–20 mins)

📖 Visit: https://www.make.com/en/learn
Look for “What is Make?” and “Getting Started.”

🔹 C. Explore Make.com Interface (Create Free Account)

  1. Go to https://www.make.com

  2. Sign up for a free account

  3. Click on “Create a new scenario”

  4. Add 2–3 apps to the board and play around (don’t need to build yet)

🔹 D. Take Notes (5–10 mins)

Create a simple Notion or Word doc with:

  • What you understood about Make.com

  • 2–3 ideas on how you can use it as a tester

✅ Summary: What You’ll Learn in This Step

You Will UnderstandExample
What Make.com does“Connect tools + automate logic”
Why it's useful to testersSave time, reduce manual work
Key terminologyScenario, trigger, module
First look at platformDrag/drop interface, simple setup

You said:
ETC - what is the meaning
ChatGPT said:

Great question!

✅ ETC stands for:

Et cetera (Latin) — meaning “and other similar things” or “and so on.”

📌 In simple terms:

It’s used when you list a few items and want to show that more similar things are included, but you don’t list them all.

✅ Example:

  • We need to test the login, registration, password reset, etc.
    → (meaning: and other similar features)

  • File names like Make_Learning_Plan, Skill_Tracker, Roadmap, etc.
    → (meaning: and other related file names)

⚠️ Common Mistakes:

  • ❌ Don't say "etc." after a complete sentence (only after a list).

  • ❌ Don’t say “and etc.” (because “et” already means “and” in Latin).

Let me know if you'd like a few examples from your field (QA or testing)!

You said:
how to capture the recording in my desktop
ChatGPT said:

To capture a recording of your desktop, you can use free or built-in tools depending on your operating system. Here's a breakdown for Windows, Mac, and third-party options:

💻 For Windows

✅ Option 1: Xbox Game Bar (Built-in)

Great for quick screen recordings (no software needed)

🔹 How to use:

  1. Press Windows + G to open Game Bar.

  2. Click the record button (or press Win + Alt + R to start/stop recording).

  3. Find recordings in:
    C:\Users\[YourName]\Videos\Captures

🎯 Use: Great for full-screen app or browser recordings.

✅ Option 2: OBS Studio (Free & Powerful)

Best for professional recordings (multiple screens, webcam, mic)

  • Download: https://obsproject.com/

  • Features: Record full screen, window, webcam, audio

  • Output: MP4, MKV, FLV, etc.

🎯 Use: Ideal for tutorials, webinars, or long demos.

🍎 For macOS

✅ Option 1: Screenshot Toolbar (Built-in)

🔹 How to use:

  1. Press Command + Shift + 5

  2. Choose from:

    • Record full screen

    • Record selected portion

  3. Click “Record”

  4. Stop from the menu bar (top-right corner)

🎯 Use: Perfect for quick, high-quality screen captures.

✅ Option 2: QuickTime Player

  1. Open QuickTime Player

  2. Go to File → New Screen Recording

  3. Select mic input (if needed)

  4. Click Record

🎯 Use: Simple, stable, and no install required.

🌐 Third-Party Tools (Cross-Platform)

ToolFeaturesLink
LoomEasy recording + sharing linksloom.com
ScreenPal (formerly Screencast-O-Matic)Simple, free, webcam overlayscreenpal.com
ShareX (Windows)Advanced, customizable, freegetsharex.com

🎙️ Want to Record Voice Too?

Make sure to select your microphone input in the tool’s settings. Most tools like OBS, QuickTime, and Loom allow you to capture both screen and mic.

You said:
how to recored while teams meeting going on
ChatGPT said:

To record while a Microsoft Teams meeting is going on, you have two main options:

✅ Option 1: Use Teams' Built-in Recording Feature

(Best for internal meetings where you're allowed to record)

🔹 Steps:

  1. Join the meeting in Microsoft Teams

  2. Click the three dots (More actions) ⋯ on the meeting toolbar

  3. Select "Start recording"

  4. A banner will appear saying: "Recording has started"

  5. To stop, click the three dots again → "Stop recording"

📍 Where is the recording saved?

  • Stored in OneDrive (for 1:1 calls) or SharePoint (for Teams channels)

  • A link to the recording will appear in the meeting chat.

⚠️ Note: Only organizers or users with recording permissions can start recording. Attendees might be notified.

✅ Option 2: Use a Screen Recorder (When Teams Recording is Disabled)

This is useful if:

  • You don’t have permission to record in Teams

  • You want to record privately for your notes

  • The meeting is external and not within your org

🔹 Tools you can use:

ToolDescription
OBS StudioFree, powerful – record screen + audio
Xbox Game Bar (Windows)Win + G → Easy screen recording (if audio is captured)
QuickTime (Mac)Cmd + Shift + 5 → Record screen + mic
Loom / ScreenPalRecord screen + mic, with cloud sharing

🔹 Steps (Example with OBS Studio):

  1. Download & install OBS: obsproject.com

  2. Add a Display Capture (to record your screen)

  3. Add Audio Input Capture (mic) and Audio Output (system sound)

  4. Click Start Recording before or during the Teams call

🎧 Want to Record Audio from the Meeting?

  • ✅ Ensure “system audio” is enabled (to capture other people's voices)

  • In OBS or ShareX: select correct audio output device

  • For Game Bar: set Teams audio as system sound

🎯 Tip: Use headphones with mic to avoid echo/feedback.

⚠️ Legal & Ethical Reminder:

Always follow company policies and local laws before recording a meeting — especially if:

  • Sensitive content is being discussed

  • Participants are external

  • Consent is not given

You can also say:

"For my notes, do you mind if I record this on my end?"

You said:
Xbox Game Bar (Windows) Win + G → Easy screen recording (if audio is captured) explain me in detail
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! Here's a detailed step-by-step guide on using Xbox Game Bar for screen recording on Windows — especially if you want to record your screen during a Teams meeting or any desktop activity.

✅ What is Xbox Game Bar?

The Xbox Game Bar is a built-in screen recording tool in Windows 10 and 11.
It allows you to:

  • Record your screen

  • Capture system audio and microphone

  • Take screenshots

  • Monitor performance (FPS, RAM, etc.)

🎯 You don’t need to install anything — it’s already in your system.

🧩 What Can It Record?

ItemCan Xbox Game Bar Record?
Fullscreen apps (e.g., Teams, browser)✅ Yes
Desktop (only)❌ No
Audio (system sound)✅ Yes
Microphone input✅ Yes
Webcam❌ No (you need OBS or Loom for webcam)

🟡 Xbox Game Bar can't record just your desktop (e.g., empty background). It must be focused on an active window like Chrome, PowerPoint, or Teams.

🛠️ Prerequisites

  1. Windows 10 (v1903 or later) or Windows 11

  2. Make sure Game Bar is enabled:

    • Go to Settings → Gaming → Xbox Game Bar

    • Turn on “Open Xbox Game Bar using this button on a controller”

🎥 How to Record Using Xbox Game Bar

🔹 Step 1: Open the app/window you want to record

  • Example: Microsoft Teams, Chrome, Excel, etc.

  • Ensure this is the active window.

🔹 Step 2: Launch Xbox Game Bar

  • Press Win + G
    (This opens the Game Bar overlay)

🎯 You’ll see a top bar with widgets: Audio, Performance, Capture, etc.

🔹 Step 3: Start Recording

  • Click the “Capture” icon (camera icon)
    If you don’t see it, press Win + Alt + R to start directly.

  • In the Capture widget, click the Record button (⏺️ red dot)

  • You’ll see a small floating bar showing “Recording”

🔹 Step 4: Record Audio (Optional)

  • Make sure your microphone is turned on
    (Toggle in Capture widget: “Turn mic on while recording”)

  • It will also record system audio (e.g., people talking in a Teams meeting)

🔹 Step 5: Stop Recording

  • Press Win + Alt + R again to stop

  • Or click the stop button on the floating toolbar

📁 Where Are Recordings Saved?

  • By default:
    C:\Users\[YourName]\Videos\Captures

You can also access them via:

  • Gallery tab in Game Bar

  • Or open your Videos > Captures folder

🔊 Audio Tips (For Meetings):

SourceCaptured by Xbox Game Bar?
Your voice (mic)✅ Yes (if enabled)
Other participants (Teams call)✅ Yes (if Teams audio plays through system)
Background system sounds✅ Yes

🔧 Tip: If you can hear the call through your speakers/headphones, it’s being captured.

⚠️ Limitations:

  • ❌ Cannot record desktop without an active app

  • ❌ No webcam recording

  • ❌ Cannot record multiple windows (just the one focused)

✅ Best Use Cases:

  • Recording Teams meetings (without official recording permission)

  • Creating tutorials or test walkthroughs

  • Capturing bugs live during test runs

Would you like a 1-minute checklist PDF or a visual guide for this process?

We want to expand the workflow with: Dynamic quoting logic based on the lease_company_format field Different email templates or PDF output formats depending on the leasing company (e.g. CompanyA, CompanyB, etc.) Automatic selection of contract format depending on the car and leasing provider explain me in detail
ChatGPT said:

Absolutely! Let’s break this down step-by-step and in simple terms — you're talking about expanding your automation workflow (likely in Make.com or a similar platform) with dynamic logic and conditional outputs, based on leasing company and car details.

🚀 Workflow Expansion Requirements – Detailed Explanation

✅ 1. Dynamic Quoting Logic Based on lease_company_format Field

🔹 What This Means:

You want the quoting rules or formulas (pricing, discounts, taxes, etc.) to change automatically based on the leasing company selected.

🔸 Example:

Lease CompanyFormat FieldLogic
CompanyAformat_aBase price + 5% admin fee
CompanyBformat_bBase price - 2% discount
CompanyCformat_cBase price + €150 documentation charge

🔹 How to Do It (In Make.com):

  1. Add a Router after your trigger

  2. Add one path per lease_company_format value (e.g. format_a, format_b)

  3. Each path includes a different set of modules or math logic for quoting

  4. Rejoin if needed later in the scenario

🧠 This enables dynamic branching — each leasing company can follow different pricing rules.

✅ 2. Different Email Templates or PDF Output Formats Based on Leasing Company

🔹 What This Means:

You want to send different versions of emails or PDFs depending on which leasing company the quote is going to.

🔸 Example:

Lease CompanyEmail TemplatePDF Format
CompanyAFormal email + classic quote layoutPDF with logo A and standard layout
CompanyBFriendly tone email + custom summaryPDF with logo B and color branding
CompanyCEmail with legal appendixPDF with terms section and watermark

🔹 How to Do It:

  1. After dynamic logic step, add a conditional branch or router for each leasing company

  2. Create:

    • Separate HTML email templates (in Text or Gmail module)

    • Different PDF templates (using PDF Generator or HTML-to-PDF tools)

  3. You can dynamically choose which template to apply by using {{lease_company_format}} as a condition

🎯 Output personalization boosts professionalism & compliance.

✅ 3. Automatic Contract Format Selection Based on Car + Leasing Provider

🔹 What This Means:

The contract document (PDF, Word, or DocuSign) must automatically match:

  • The type of car (e.g. electric, diesel, luxury)

  • The leasing provider (e.g. CompanyA, CompanyB)

🔸 Example:

Car TypeLeasing ProviderContract Format
ElectricCompanyAEco-friendly clause + template A
DieselCompanyBHigh mileage clause + template B
LuxuryCompanyCPremium terms + CompanyC layout

🔹 How to Do It:

  1. Use a combined condition (e.g. IF car_type = electric AND lease_company = CompanyA)

  2. Each path triggers a different contract template (PDF, Docx, DocuSign)

  3. Store contract formats in a central drive or use an HTML-based generator

  4. Output is attached to email or routed to signing

🧠 You can make this fully dynamic using a lookup table or database (e.g. Airtable, Google Sheets) where rules are mapped.

🧩 Tools You Might Use in Make.com

FeatureTool/Module
ConditionsRouters or Filters
EmailGmail, Outlook, Email module
PDFHTML-to-PDF, PDF Generator API
TemplatesText module with HTML
Logic branchingVariables, If/Else modules
Lookup valuesData Store, Google Sheets, Airtable

✅ Summary

RequirementApproach
Dynamic quoting logicUse lease_company_format in Routers or logic steps
Email/PDF templatesRoute based on company name → apply correct templates
Contract format selectionCombine car_type + leasing_provider → select template or doc

Let’s break it down in detail:

🔍 What is Make.com?

Make.com (formerly Integromat) is a no-code automation platform. It allows you to connect apps and services (like Google Sheets, Slack, HubSpot, etc.) to automate repetitive tasks—without needing to write code.

You build automations using a visual drag-and-drop scenario builder.

🎯 Use Cases

Some real-world examples of Make.com automation include:

Use CaseExample
CRM automationSync leads from HubSpot to a database like Supabase
MarketingAuto-send emails to new subscribers from a Google Form
SalesNotify the sales team on Slack when a new deal is created
FinanceCreate an invoice in Moneybird when a new order is placed

✅ Benefits

BenefitExplanation
No-code / beginner-friendlyDrag, drop, and connect apps visually
FlexibleSupports hundreds of apps and custom APIs
Real-time & scheduled triggersAutomate tasks instantly or on a timer
Error handling & loggingHelps you track and debug issues
Cost-effectiveOffers a generous free plan and affordable paid plans

Here’s what you should do:

  1. 🔗 Visit https://make.com

  2. 📝 Sign up for a free account (just need email)

    • Scenario Builder – where you create automations

You said:
{"message":"The request failed due to failure of a previous request.","code":"SC424","suberrors":[{"message":"Account error (invalid_client)","name":"Error"}]} this error occures when we connect with make.com
ChatGPT said:

The error message you’re seeing:

json
{"message":"The request failed due to failure of a previous request.","code":"SC424","suberrors":[{"message":"Account error (invalid_client)","name":"Error"}]}

is a Make.com integration error, typically triggered during OAuth2-based authentication — especially with services like HubSpot, Microsoft, Google, etc.

❗ Error Explanation

🔹 Error CodeSC424
🔹 MeaningA request failed because a previous (auth) request failed
🔹 Suberror"invalid_client" = The client ID or secret used is incorrect or unrecognized by the service you're connecting to

🔍 Common Causes

  1. Wrong or expired credentials (Client ID / Client Secret)

  2. Redirect URL mismatch between Make.com and the app’s developer console

  3. OAuth app not authorized properly by the connected account

  4. Sandbox vs production confusion (especially with Salesforce, Zoho, etc.)

🛠️ How to Fix It (Step by Step)

✅ 1. Check your connection settings

  • Go to Make.com → Connections

  • Edit or recreate the connection

  • Make sure the correct account is selected

  • Reauthorize the app when prompted

✅ 2. Verify Client Credentials

If you're using a custom OAuth app, make sure:

FieldWhat to Check
Client IDCopied exactly from the developer console
Client SecretNot expired or incorrect
Redirect URIMust match the one Make.com uses (e.g. https://www.make.com/oauth/cb/...)

✅ 3. Delete & Reconnect

  • Delete the faulty connection from Make

  • Re-add it, selecting the correct account and permissions

  • If it’s Google, Microsoft, HubSpot, etc., ensure pop-ups aren't blocked

✅ 4. Use Make.com Help Links

If you're integrating with a specific app (e.g., HubSpot), check Make’s help pages:

  • Make.com – HubSpot help

  • Make.com OAuth guide

🧪 Bonus: Testing tip

  • Create a new scenario with just the authentication module

  • Run it once to isolate the auth failure before adding logic

Would you like me to walk you through reconnecting a specific service like HubSpot, Google, or Supabase? Just let me know the platform!

You said:
how to connect the make with the google form
ChatGPT said:

Connecting Make.com with Google Forms lets you automate tasks like storing responses in databases, sending emails, Slack alerts, or even creating CRM leads — all without writing code.

✅ Goal:

Trigger an automation in Make.com every time someone submits a Google Form.

🛠️ What You’ll Need:

ToolPurpose
Google FormsTo collect responses
Google SheetsStores Form responses (used as the actual trigger)
Make.comTo automate the workflow

🔄 How It Works:

Google Forms doesn't directly connect to Make. Instead:

  1. Google Form → Automatically logs data in a Google Sheet

  2. Make watches that Google Sheet for new rows

  3. When a new row appears → Trigger your automation (email, Slack, database insert, etc.)

🧭 Step-by-Step: Connect Google Form to Make.com

🔹 1. Create a Google Form

  • Go to Google Forms

  • Add questions (e.g., Name, Email, Message)

🔹 2. Connect the Form to a Google Sheet

  • Click on “Responses” tab in Google Form

  • Click the Google Sheets icon → it creates a new linked Sheet

This Sheet now updates every time someone submits the form.

🔹 3. In Make.com

a. Create a New Scenario

  • Go to Make.com → Scenarios → + Create a new scenario

b. Add the Google Sheets module

  • Select: Google Sheets → Watch Rows

  • It will trigger when new responses are added to your form

c. Connect your Google account

  • Make will ask you to authorize your Google account

  • Make sure to grant access to Sheets

d. Configure the Module

  • Select the Sheet linked to your Form

  • Choose the worksheet (usually “Form Responses 1”)

  • Set trigger condition:

    • From now on = only new responses

    • Or from a specific row

🔹 4. Add Next Steps

You can now chain any of these:

  • Send an email (Gmail or Outlook module)

  • Create a record in Airtable/Supabase

  • Send alert to Slack

  • Create CRM lead (HubSpot, Pipedrive, etc.)

  • Generate PDF or invoice

🔹 5. Save & Run

  • Click Save

  • Turn the scenario ON

  • Click Run once to test with a new form submission

Yes? Here's a recommended YouTube guide:
👉 Automate Google Form Responses in Make.com (YouTube)

You said:
SMTP server* how can i find the for the gmail account
ChatGPT said:

To use your Gmail account as an SMTP server, you’ll need a few settings and permissions. Here's how to find and set it up step-by-step:

📬 What Is SMTP?

SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol) allows Make.com (or any app) to send emails using your Gmail account.

🔧 Gmail SMTP Server Settings

SettingValue
SMTP Serversmtp.gmail.com
Port587 (for TLS) or 465 (for SSL)
EncryptionSTARTTLS (for port 587) or SSL/TLS (for port 465)
UsernameYour full Gmail address (e.g. yourname@gmail.com)
Password⚠️ App Password (see below – you can’t use your regular password)

🔐 Step-by-Step Setup with Gmail

✅ 1. Enable 2-Step Verification

You must enable this before using app passwords.

  • Go to: https://myaccount.google.com/security

  • Turn on 2-Step Verification under “Signing in to Google”

✅ 2. Generate an App Password (for SMTP)

Regular Gmail passwords won’t work with SMTP. You must create a one-time app password:

  1. Visit: https://myaccount.google.com/apppasswords

  2. Sign in

  3. Under "Select app" → choose "Mail"

  4. Under "Select device" → choose "Other", name it like “Make SMTP”

  5. Click Generate

  6. Google gives you a 16-character password — copy it

📌 Use this password in Make.com, not your normal Gmail password.

✅ 3. In Make.com – Use SMTP Module

When using Make’s SMTP module:

  • Host: smtp.gmail.com

  • Port: 587

  • Username: yourname@gmail.com

  • Password: (Paste the App Password)

  • TLS Encryption: STARTTLS (recommended)

🧪 Test Email in Make

After setting it up, try sending a test email using the SMTP module in Make. If it fails, double-check:

  • App password is correct

  • 2FA is turned ON

  • SMTP server + port are set properly

  • A pre-built Make SMTP scenario?

  • Gmail → Send email → Attach PDF or form responses?

You said:
You have to choose Google connection or use our Gmail package for Google accounts. Common SMTP connection can't be used for Google accounts because of the different authorization methods. this error occurs while connecting the email in make
ChatGPT said:

Great question — and you're right to raise this!

❌ Why You’re Seeing This Error

Make.com shows:

“You have to choose Google connection or use our Gmail package for Google accounts. Common SMTP connection can't be used for Google accounts because of the different authorization methods.”

🔍 This means:

You’re trying to use Gmail with the generic SMTP module, which won’t work due to Google’s OAuth security policies (especially after May 30, 2022).

✅ Solution: Use the Gmail Module, Not SMTP

🔄 Two Options:

OptionDescription
✅ Gmail module (recommended)Built-in Gmail integration in Make.com with OAuth
❌ SMTP module with GmailBlocked by Google (unless you're using App Password + very specific cases)

✅ How to Use Gmail with Make.com

1. In your scenario, click ➕ and search for “Gmail”

  • Select the Gmail module (e.g., Send an email, Watch emails)

2. Click “Add” or “Connect”

  • A popup will open asking you to sign in with your Google account

  • Grant access to the necessary scopes (Send email, Read, etc.)

3. Once authorized, Make.com will save this as a Gmail connection

  • You can reuse it in multiple modules/scenarios

🧩 Gmail Module vs SMTP – Why It Matters

FeatureGmail ModuleSMTP Module
Google-compliant auth✅ OAuth 2.0❌ App passwords only
Attachments✅ Yes✅ Yes
Send emails✅ Yes✅ Yes (but often blocked)
Security✅ Very secure⚠️ Deprecated / blocked by Gmail

🔐 Note for Workspace (G Suite) Accounts

If you're using a Google Workspace account, ensure:

  • Admin has allowed 3rd-party apps like Make.com

  • Gmail API access is not restricted

🚫 Avoid using SMTP for Gmail in Make

If you're using smtp.gmail.com in the SMTP module, you'll likely get blocked unless:

  • You’re using App Passwords

  • You have an older or legacy Gmail setup

But this is no longer recommended. Google prefers OAuth-based access only, which is what Make’s Gmail module uses.

✅ What To Do Now

  1. Go to your scenario

  2. Delete the SMTP module

  3. Add the Gmail module

  4. Click Connect → login with your Gmail → allow access

  5. Configure your email send/receive logic

Yes, you can send data to WhatsApp using Make.com, but not directly for free — it requires integrating with a WhatsApp Business API provider like:

✅ Common WhatsApp API Providers You Can Use with Make.com

ProviderNotes
TwilioPopular, easy to connect, good docs
360dialogOfficial WhatsApp BSP (Business Service Provider); used by many CRMs
WATI.ioNo-code friendly, good for business messaging
Zoko, Gupshup, AiSensyAlso offer WhatsApp API access with Make or webhook support

🔧 How to Send WhatsApp Messages via Make.com

🔹 Option 1: Use Twilio + WhatsApp

Steps:

  1. Create a Twilio account: https://www.twilio.com/whatsapp

  2. Get a WhatsApp-enabled phone number (Twilio will guide you)

  3. In Make.com:

    • Add a module: Twilio → Send a Message

    • Set the "From" as your Twilio number

    • Set the "To" as the recipient (with country code)

    • Message Type: WhatsApp

    • Write your message (can include data from a form, CRM, etc.)

🔹 Option 2: Use Webhooks with 360dialog or WATI

If your BSP (like 360dialog) supports incoming HTTP requests:

  1. Set up a webhook in Make (use HTTP module)

  2. Send POST request to the BSP's WhatsApp API

  3. Format the JSON payload with your message + phone number

  2. Search for your bot by username (e.g., @carDealerAlerts_bot)

This activates your bot.

🔍 B. Get Your Chat ID

To get your chat ID:

Option 1: Use a bot to find it

  1. Search for and message @userinfobot

  2. It will reply with your Telegram user_id (this is your chat ID)

Option 2: Use this link in your browser:

bash
https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR_BOT_TOKEN>/getUpdates

Replace <YOUR_BOT_TOKEN> with the token you got from BotFather.

If you already messaged your bot, you’ll see something like:

json
"chat": {
  "id": 123456789,
  "first_name": "Prabu",
  "type": "private"
}

✅ The id is your chat ID

👥 Option 2: Sending to a Group or Channel

  1. Add your bot to the group

  2. Promote it to admin (so it can post messages)

  3. Send a message in the group

  4. Use the same getUpdates method to see the group’s chat.id

📝 Group chat IDs usually start with -100...

  2. Create a new scenario

csharp

The error:

css

in Make.com → Telegram Bot module means that the bot is trying to send a message to a chat ID that it hasn’t interacted with or doesn’t have permission to access.

🔍 Common Causes & Fixes

❌ Problem 1: User has not started the bot

✅ Fix:

Before a bot can message someone (even you), the user must click “Start” in the chat with the bot.

Steps:

  1. Search for your bot in Telegram (e.g., @MyAlertBot)

  2. Open the chat

  3. Tap “Start”

➡️ Now your bot is authorized to send you messages.

❌ Problem 2: Wrong or invalid Chat ID

✅ Fix:

Double-check the Chat ID you're using:

  • Use @userinfobot to get your correct personal chat ID

  • Or use:

    bash
    https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR_BOT_TOKEN>/getUpdates

    to check active chat IDs after starting the bot

✅ Make sure you paste the correct numerical ID (like 123456789) into the “Chat ID” field in Make.com.

❌ Problem 3: Bot is sending messages to a group without permission

✅ Fix:

If you’re sending to a Telegram group:

  1. Add your bot to the group

  2. Make it an admin

  3. Send a test message in the group

  4. Go to:

    bash
    https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR_BOT_TOKEN>/getUpdates

    Get the correct group Chat ID (starts with -100...)

  5. Use that ID in Make

❌ Problem 4: Bot is not connected properly in Make

✅ Fix:

In Make.com:

  • Reconnect your Telegram Bot module

  • Paste the exact token you got from BotFather

  • Make sure there are no extra spaces

Great question! You're working with the Telegram Bot → Send a Message module in Make.com, and some of the fields may look confusing.

Here’s a clear explanation of what each field means, and what you actually need to fill in vs what you can leave blank. ✅

✅ Required Fields

FieldWhat to EnterRequired?
Chat IDThe recipient’s chat ID (123456789 or -100...)✅ Yes
TextThe message you want to send✅ Yes

🧪 Optional Fields – What They Mean

1. Message Thread ID

  • Used only for sending replies inside topics in Telegram forums (groups with topics enabled).

  • Leave it blank unless you’re replying to a topic thread.

✅ Leave blank if sending to user, regular group, or channel.

2. Parse Mode

Defines how text is formatted.

OptionWhat it does
MarkdownEnables bold, italics, etc. using *text*, _text_, etc.
HTMLUse <b>, <i>, <code> etc. for formatting

✅ Choose Markdown or HTML if you want rich formatting.
❌ Leave blank for plain text.

3. Disable Notifications

  • Turn ON if you want to send the message silently (no sound on recipient’s phone).

  • true = no notification sound

  • false = regular notification

✅ Leave blank unless you specifically want silent messages.

4. Disable Link Previews

  • true = Telegram won’t show link preview thumbnails

  • false = Telegram shows preview when sending a link

✅ Useful if you want to send clean text with links but no previews.

5. Original Message ID

  • Use this if you're replying to a specific previous message

  • Only works in groups or channels

✅ Leave blank unless you're automating replies to earlier messages.

6. Reply Markup

This is for custom buttons/keyboards in Telegram (optional advanced UI).

You can use:

  • Inline buttons (InlineKeyboardMarkup)

  • Reply buttons (ReplyKeyboardMarkup)

  • Remove or force keyboard

Example (Inline buttons):

json
{
  "inline_keyboard": [
    [
      { "text": "View Order", "url": "https://yourapp.com/order/123" }
    ]
  ]
}

✅ Use this only if you want buttons in the message.
❌ Otherwise, leave blank.

✅ Minimum Fields to Send a Basic Message

Just fill:

  • Chat ID (e.g. 123456789)

  • Text (e.g. Hello, your request is confirmed!)

Everything else is optional.

✅ Example: Send a Message with Bold Text & No Link Preview

FieldValue

Parse ModeMarkdown
Disable Link Previewstrue

To generate a Webhook URL for a form in Make.com, you need to use the “Webhook” module as the trigger in your Make scenario. Here’s a complete step-by-step guide for generating the webhook URL and connecting it to your form (like Google Forms, Typeform, or a custom HTML form):

✅ Step-by-Step: Generate Webhook URL in Make.com

🔹 1. Login to Make.com

  • Open the Make.com dashboard

  • Click Create a new scenario

🔹 2. Add a Webhook Module as the Trigger

  • In the blank scenario, click the + button

  • Search for: “Webhooks”

  • Select: Webhooks → Custom webhook

  • Click: Add

🔹 3. Create a New Webhook

  • Click “Add” again in the webhook setup window

  • Enter a name like FormSubmission

  • Click Save

✅ Now Make.com will generate a Webhook URL, like:

arduino
https://hook.make.com/xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

🔹 4. Copy the Webhook URL

  • Copy the full URL

  • Keep this tab open — Make will now “listen” for test data

🧪 Example: Send Data from an HTML Form

Here’s how you might send form data to the webhook:

html
<form action="https://hook.make.com/xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx" method="POST">
  <input type="text" name="name" placeholder="Your Name" />
  <input type="email" name="email" placeholder="Your Email" />
  <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>

✅ When the form is submitted → data goes directly to Make.com

If you're using Google Forms:

  • Use an add-on like Form Submit or [Google Apps Script] to call the Make webhook

    email: e.namedValues["Email"]
  }

Perfect! Hosting a form on Vercel for free is a great choice — it’s fast, modern, and beginner-friendly. Here’s how to do it step-by-step, even if you’re not a developer.

✅ Goal

Host a form HTML page on Vercel.com that users can submit → sends data to a Make.com Webhook.

🛠 What You’ll Need

ToolWhy
VercelFree hosting platform
GitHub (free account)Needed to deploy your code via Vercel
A webhook from Make.comWhere your form data will go

✅ Step-by-Step Guide

🔹 1. Create the HTML Form

Create a file called index.html with this content:

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8" />
  <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0" />
  <title>Submit Form</title>
</head>
<body>
  <h2>Contact Form</h2>
  <form action="https://hook.make.com/YOUR_WEBHOOK_ID" method="POST">
    <label for="name">Name:</label>
    <input name="name" type="text" required /><br><br>

    <label for="email">Email:</label>
    <input name="email" type="email" required /><br><br>

    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
  </form>
</body>
</html>

🔁 Replace YOUR_WEBHOOK_ID with the actual webhook ID you created in Make.com.

🔹 2. Push to GitHub

  1. Create a GitHub account if you don't have one

  2. Create a new repository (public or private)

  3. Upload the index.html file (you can drag-drop in the GitHub UI)

🔹 3. Connect GitHub to Vercel

  1. Go to https://vercel.com and sign in with GitHub

  2. Click “Add New Project”

  3. Select your repo (the one with index.html)

  4. Click Deploy

🔹 4. Done! 🎉

Your site will be live at:

To send Telegram bot messages to a group, you need to follow these 4 required steps very carefully:

✅ STEP-BY-STEP: Send Telegram Bot Message to a Group

🔹 Step 1: Add the Bot to Your Group

  1. Go to your group in the Telegram app.

  2. Tap the group name > “Add Members”

  3. Search for your bot name (e.g., @CarDealerAlertbot) and add it to the group.

🔹 Step 2: Promote the Bot to Admin (Important!)

  1. After adding the bot, tap the group name again.

  2. Go to "Administrators" > tap your bot > Enable permissions:

    • ✅ Can send messages

    • ✅ Can pin/edit/delete messages (optional)

  3. Tap Save / Checkmark

Without admin permission, the bot cannot send messages.

🔹 Step 3: Send a Message in the Group

You or someone must send any message in the group after adding the bot. This is required so Telegram can generate an update that includes the group chat ID.

🔹 Step 4: Get the Group chat_id

Now open this link (use your actual bot token):

bash
https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR_BOT_TOKEN>/getUpdates

For your case:

ruby
https://api.telegram.org/bot7746615468:AAEhZnnwouuko7XiZQ9da_t16-UFFN-tkEY/getUpdates

Check the JSON output — look for:

json
"chat": {
  "id": -1001234567890,
  "title": "Your Group Name",
  ...
}

✅ That id (starting with -100) is your group chat ID.

🔹 Step 5: Send a Message to the Group

Now use this URL:

bash
https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR_BOT_TOKEN>/sendMessage?chat_id=<GROUP_CHAT_ID>&text=Hello+from+your+bot

Example:

ruby

Here’s a detailed breakdown of the workflow in your table — this is a 3-stage automation process combining HubSpot, Supabase, and Slack, aimed at syncing leads and alerting the sales team about high-quality ones.

🔧 1. Planning & Setup

This is the foundation stage — preparing everything before the automation begins.

✅ Define workflow steps

  • Clearly outline what happens from lead generation to Slack alert.

  • Identify all tools involved: HubSpot, Supabase, Make/Integromat (for automation), and Slack.

✅ Access tools and collect API keys

  • Generate API keys/tokens from:

    • HubSpot (for contacts and lead data)

    • Supabase (for database read/write access)

    • Slack (for sending messages via webhook or bot)

  • This step ensures each tool can communicate securely with the others.

✅ Prepare Supabase schema

  • Design a table in Supabase like:

    sql
    leads (
  id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
  email TEXT,
  first_name TEXT,
  last_name TEXT,
  phone TEXT,
  lead_score INT,
  created_at TIMESTAMP
)

  • This schema will store lead information synced from HubSpot.

🔄 2. HubSpot ↔ Supabase Lead Sync

This part of the automation moves lead data between HubSpot and Supabase.

✅ Sync new leads from HubSpot to Supabase

  • Use automation (like Make.com or code) to:

    • Detect new leads created in HubSpot

    • Insert them into the Supabase leads table

✅ Keep contact data updated bidirectionally

  • Ensure updates on either side are reflected on the other:

    • If a lead's phone number is updated in HubSpot, Supabase should reflect it.

    • If Supabase adds a tag or qualification, sync it back to HubSpot.

Tools to use:

  • Make/Integromat scenario with HubSpot and Supabase modules

  • Or build a Node.js/Python script that runs on a scheduler or webhook trigger

📈 3. Lead Qualification + Slack Alert

This step helps your sales team act fast on valuable leads.

✅ Detect high-quality leads

  • Based on fields like:

    • Job title

    • Company size

    • Lead score (e.g., above 80)

  • You can automate this using filters in Supabase or logic inside your automation platform.

✅ Send Slack alerts to sales team

  • Use a Slack webhook or bot to post messages:

    • Example:

      vbnet
      🔔 New High-Quality Lead:
Name: Jane Doe
Score: 92
Email: jane@company.com

  • Trigger this Slack alert whenever a new high-quality lead is inserted or updated in Supabase.

🔁 Overall Workflow Summary

  1. Setup and connect APIs

  2. Sync new leads from HubSpot → Supabase

  3. Monitor for high-quality leads in Supabase

  4. Alert sales via Slack instantly
